text: in case my love letter to AnoHana didn't
make it abundantly clear I stand pretty
hard for Mario cata as an English
speaker it can be a bit hard to fully
appreciate the more subtle lyrical
qualities of her dialogue but anyone can
see and appreciate the depth and
humanity that she writes into her
characters whenever I hear that she's
writing an original script for an anime
I get excited so naturally when I saw
that hana saku Aloha and blast of
tempest director masahito Ando was
slated to adapt Okada's first manga o
maidens in your savage season and that
she would be composing the script for it
it immediately became one of my most
anticipated shows of the summer and as
high as my height for this show was I am
happy to report that thus far it has
more than lived up to it o maidens bears
all the hallmarks of both creators best
works it's a tale of nuanced
well-developed characters struggling to
understand their own turbulent emotions
which are externalized brilliantly
through bold subjective camerawork and
editing but where many of Okada's
best-known works and both of her
previous collaborations with ando have
been more on the serious and dramatic
side of the anime spectrum this show
builds itself first and foremost as a
comedy and holy crap what a glorious
gut-busting hardy cackle laugh of a
comedy it is with its twisted sense of
humor and uncompromising approach to its
subject matter this show has made me
giggle more and harder than any other
comedy I've seen so far this year and
I'm here today to tell you why you need
to sit down and watch or read it also
today or failing that as soon as humanly
possible as its title so poetically
hints o maidens in your savage season
seeks to explore perhaps the single
funniest and most painful stage of
almost every person's life puberty the
series follows five awkward geeky girls
in a high school literature club as
their noble scholarly pursuits are
progressively waylaid by hormonal
impulses sexual desires and a growing
realization that if you look at it the
right way literally everything on the
planet is a lewd euphemism our heroine
is kazusa Ohno Dara a quiet girl with
nothing really special about her which
as her best friend
and clubmate Momoko sudo is keen to
point out kind of makes her special in
its own way
lately kazusa has found herself thinking
a lot about her next-door neighbor and
childhood friend
Azumi who's gradually grown apart from
her or to be more accurate been pulled
away from her by other jealous girls
after hitting a growth spurt and getting
hot that's not the only kind of hot
spurt that causes a season experience
but we'll get to that first let me
introduce the rest of the literature
club
Momoko is about as shy and soft-spoken
escazu is but she hasn't gone quite as
boy-crazy though she has started to
fixate a bit on how beautiful and
elegant their other best friend nina
sugawara is hmm nina for her part at
first seems like a bit of an outlier in
the motley crew of dorks a cool beauty
and former child actress who catches the
eye of every boy at school but in a way
that can be just as isolating for a girl
as getting no attention at all and the
literature Club is the only place where
she can really be herself
the blunt heat oh haha go is the club's
resident aspiring writer who's been
tasked by her obnoxious [ __ ] editor
to write an erotic novel that he can
then sell as the audacious debut of a
high school genius knowing literally
nothing about sex she's taken to
researching it through online chat rooms
which I'm sure won't go wrong in any way
lastly there's club president Rika Sona
Zaki an outspoken hardcore prude who
wants nothing to do with boys damn it so
stop talking about them and making her
think about them and that one boy had
better stop being so darn cute nice ah
they're infuriating yeah the series has
a lot of fun with her and with all of
them because while puberty sucks when
you're going through it it is hilarious
in hindsight and when you see it happen
to someone else as the great Mel Brooks
once said tragedy is when I cut my
finger
comedy is when you fall in an open sewer
and die highschool rom-coms like this
often default the drawing humor from
comedic ly exaggerated misunderstandings
and don't get me wrong when those
scenarios are handled well they can be a
laugh riot
but seeing so many shows lean into the
same formula time and again
tedious after a while and stories driven
by that trope by their nature tend to
move kind of slowly a big part of Oh
Maiden charm is that it often bucks that
trend it's characters do talk past each
other hide things from each other and
just not get each other sometimes
they're teenagers after all but puberty
is characterized as much by sudden hyper
awareness and moments of clarity like
finally getting the raunchy jokes
embedded in every family film as it is
by confusion and Oh Maiden really enjoys
playing up those shocking revelations
for comedic effect the first scene in
the show that really had me rolling on
the floor for example was cazzo says
rude awakening from herself perpetuated
delusion that easily is still just a
good little boy who loves nothing more
than he loves trains and who wouldn't
even think about that sort of thing the
scene begins with cosmoses mom sending
her next-door to deliver some leftovers
to ease a mate when she arrives she
finds the house dark and empty with
faint sounds of music coming from the
top floor causes a slow climb up the
darkened stairway plays out like
something out of a horror movie
tension building as the music grows
louder until eventually she peeks
through the door and sees literally the
only thing you'd expect to see in a
teenage boys room with the music
blasting when no one's home after
processing the scene before her for a
few moments kazusa runs away screaming
and Sprint's frantically through a
cityscape full of innuendo before
stopping to contemplate the implications
of a train going into a tunnel a
well-worn sight gag to be sure but it's
a classic for a reason
the scenes a laugh riot and it shows how
world defining sex can be when you first
become aware of it
kazusa and her club mates don't really
want to think about SE baat su as they
put it but more and more it's getting to
be all they can think about and as the
image of easily in her mind gets tangled
up in the monolithic concept of
copulation that internal paradox puts
more and more strain on their already
difficult friendship whether the bonds
between them will strengthen or shatter
under this new pressure remains to be
seen but the series makes it clear
there's still hope
puberty changes everything but at the
same time for all that does change the
people who experience it do largely stay
the same
another paradox that the series delights
in exploring Oh maidens is commendable
for its entertainment value alone but
amid all the jokes and drama there are
hints of nobler aspirations the show is
keen to bring up the idea that great
literature can help us put into concrete
terms emotions and experiences that
we're struggling to understand cow
sosenko will often relate their own
feelings to passages and books they've
been reading and one of the show's
favorite gags is having characters tease
each other with double entendre x' and
saucy scenes and the books they're
reading aloud in the same vein o maidens
aims to provide its viewers and readers
with a bit of unconventional sex
education by having its characters
openly experience the uncomfortable
sometimes unhealthy emotions and desires
that come with sexual awakening aspects
that most stories about teenage romance
tend to gloss over allowing in theory
for its younger readers and viewers to
put words to things that other stories
ignore it is rare to see anime and manga
tackle this subject matter in such a
thoughtful way and rarer still to see
any real exploration of puberty from a
girl's perspective especially in a
shounen imprint romantic comedies for
teenage boys can be pretty risky but
their aim when they go there is almost
always titillation not romantic
catharsis and their equivalent for
teenage girls tends to emphasize a pure
chaste ideal of love that let's be real
here doesn't exist while I don't think
their intent is bad both kinds of love
story can leave their generally young
confused and impressionable audiences
with unrealistic and unhealthy
expectations in regards to love and sex
creating the impression that their to
the whole these separate things when
even if they are making that separation
isn't something that most teenagers let
alone most adults are equipped to do o
maidens in contrast is largely about how
separating those two aspects of romance
can be next to impossible and the stress
that's struggling to do so while also
dealing with society's expectations can
put on a developing mind causes
difficulties in separating her memories
of who easily was her feelings for who
he is and her urges to welcome you know
while also dealing with all the girls
who see her as a threat are just one
exam
of this ricca-san pies puritanical
attitude towards sex and romance likely
a product of those unrealistically pure
love stories puts her at odds with most
of her class and puts a lot of strain on
her when she starts catching feelings
for the class clown should the ideal
that she strives for of chaste scholarly
nobility clearly isn't making her happy
and it's certainly going to be hell on
any potential romantic partner watching
them both work to tear those walls down
feels really satisfying this being a
Mario kata joint there are of course a
few tear-jerking moments mixed in with
all the laughs but in contrast to the
likes of AnoHana
Oh Maiden seemingly prefers to go for
tears of joy over misery one of the
first scenes that really got me comes
when shin-chan's Rika a 50 page essay
about why he likes her 49 of those pages
are just the word cute written over and
over but as simple as it is that praise
coming from someone she loves manages to
wash away a mountain of hurt feelings
and insecurities built up by years of
bullying and cruel schoolyard gossip
that scene hits Rica's story thus far
has delivered the most unambiguously
heartwarming moments in the series she
also develops a slow growing friendship
with judo so no a a pretty and popular
Yahoo from her class who's not shy about
how much she likes doing it with her
boyfriend the nice sexually confident
guru is a bit of a trope at this point
but I'm a bit of a sucker for it and
something about their interactions just
puts a big smile on my face that trope
is certainly fitting for a series about
girls pushing back against society's
expectations of them a theme that's most
prominent in Nina su kawaras arc as I
said Nina's pretty and popular with the
boys around her but that's not an
entirely good thing she's been dealing
with the pressure of men's sexual
expectations for a lot longer than the
rest of the girls and from a much
younger age than anyone should have to
think about that which has clearly
[ __ ] her up she also has to deal
constantly with jealousy from the girls
around her which makes her just as much
a target for bullying as Rica she's got
a deep interest in sex tempered by a
twisted view of what it entails for
reasons that will touch on shortly and
it's heavily implied that she's at least
thinking about committing suicide if and
when
yokatta goes for more on brand
tear-jerking
I'm willing to bet that Nina will be at
the center of it though I'm hoping the
series will ultimately offer positive
solutions for what she and the other
maidens are going through Oh maiden
story is still ongoing so I can't say
for sure where it will end up but as
it's written I think it already offers
some great tools for helping its
adolescent audience better understand
what they their friends and their
crushes are going through while
delivering uproarious comedy and
compelling mostly uncle' shade romantic
tension the series does take some of its
characters to pretty dark taboo places
which might understandably leave a bad
taste in some viewers mouths but what
separates it in my mind from trashy
romance stories like say citrus or
domestic girlfriend is that it offers up
commentary on and criticism of these
taboo scenarios instead of simply
depicting them to make the story feel
more racy and exciting it's revealed
early on that Nina's emotional hang-ups
and cavalier attitude towards sex are in
part the byproduct of years of pseudo
sexual grooming by the pedophilic
director of her theater troupe while
Nina doesn't yet fully understand how
badly this abuse has harmed her through
Izumi's reactions the series makes it
abundantly clear up front that he is
meant to be viewed as a class-a creep
and that what he did to Nina what he
projected onto her even though he never
did anything with her was fundamentally
not okay and in a cultural climate where
games can be torn down from store
shelves because an actor enjoyed a bit
of booger sugar while Nobuhiro Watsuki
gets to keep writing rurouni kenshin
after being fined $2,000 for possession
of child porn I think that framing the
scenario with that context is really
damned important equally damned
important is omate ins inclusion of an
explicitly gay character in Momoko more
than any of the other maidens she
struggles to properly identify what
she's going through because so little of
the literature she can read represents
the experiences of a homosexual kid
she's very obviously attracted to Nina
but she hasn't been given the words to
express and understand that attraction
yet
puberty's hard on everyone but from what
my LGBTQ friends tell me it's a
specially difficult when most of the
formative media you experience doesn't
acknowledge that you exist
so it's great that Oh maidens represents
alternative sexualities at all and
especially great that it specifically
explores how lonely an experienced
puberty can be for a gay kid with lots
of straight friends through Momoko's
eyes were also shown how uncomfortable
unwanted romantic advances can be
she's bombarded with text by an old
elementary school classmate who's a nice
guy who pays for tiny fractions of girls
meals because that's what nice guys do
you know who just wants to be friends
and maybe help her break out of her
shell a bit because she's so shy you
know essentially he's projecting his own
feelings and intentions onto her instead
of making any effort to understand where
she's coming from and the way he
communicates as a result of this is
exasperating annoying and yeah in
general I think this series is as
valuable for boys going through puberty
as it is for girls offering a window
into the heads of what can seem like
alien creatures at that stage of life
and in particular I think that seeing
what it's like to be on the receiving
end of an uninvited barrage of
well-intentioned texts is something that
will open a lot of young stupid eyes at
the very least I know that's something
teenage Jeff could have benefited from

book Walker is my go-to choice for
reading on the go and once you try it

book Walker is giving mother's basement
viewers 600 yen off any book on their
store and all you got to do to claim it
is use the promo code basement when you
check out as you can probably guess one
of the books they have is the O maidens
in your savage season manga which is
just as fantastic as the anime and
rather than picking one over the
I'd strongly recommend experiencing both
where the anime leverages the strengths
of cinema to deliver its jokes and help
you get inside its characters
pathologically horny heads the manga
makes impeccable use of panel spacing
and layout to achieve similar results
the tense multi-page spread that leads
up to kazusa walking in on Azumi and the
slow reveal that follows is masterful in
its own right in the manga and the
series keeps up that level of visual
comedy throughout book walkers
high-resolution scans make it easy to
appreciate the finer details of omae's
ins gorgeous artwork but whether you buy
this series or any of the other
wonderful manga and light novels on book
walker just make sure you use that promo
code basement when you check out to get

okay I'm back and the power of Schilling
has purged the shame from my body o
maidens in your savage season does have
a few blind spots in its exploration of
sexuality it doesn't really touch on
asexuals for instance and that's a shame
because nothing does but it handles the
subjects that it does choose to tackle
smartly using salacious subject matter
to create powerful comedy and drama and
justifying that use by always having
something to say about it well almost
always
Hong goes on story arc which sees her
trying to charge headfirst into
adulthood with the aid of her chat
partner meelo who without spoiling
things is obviously a lot older than she
is goes to some decidedly question of
all places while it's clear that he's
not into highschool girls at all in the
feelings she develops for him are
entirely one-sided he doesn't exactly
discourage them or her advances and the
series doesn't really paint him as a bad
guy like it does Nina's director either
the justification for this seems to be
that he wants to help Hong go better
understand her sexuality so that she can
be a better writer and that she's
blackmailing him to some extent but this
storyline is still an absolute minefield
of potentially unfortunate implications
and it's only because of the show's deft
handling of everything else as well as
my aforementioned standing for Okada
that I have any hope that it will be
resolved in a satisfying fashion I will
certainly be sad if it isn't because
Hongo is easily my favorite member of
the core cast as someone who was once an
aspiring teenage writer there's
obviously a lot
about her that I can relate to and the
devastating deadpan sass bombs that
she's proven capable of dropping are
just delightful even with that edge of
personal relatability Hongo doesn't come
out too far ahead of the rest of the
cast in my personal rankings list every
member of the literature Club and most
of the supporting characters surrounding
them are thoroughly charming in their
own right and the supportive dynamic of
the core group of girls in particular
gives me a similar vibe to a place
further than the universe which is about
as high praise as one can conceivably
give to a female centric coming-of-age
anime the nature of this story and the
dramatic demands of its genre tell me
that these bookworms probably won't
always be on the friendliest of terms
with each other but the show's done such
a great job of endearing me to them that
if they ever do come to harder blows
than a pillow fight I'm not sure I'll
know who to root for and that to me is a
sign of truly great character writing we
really are spoiled for choice with all
of the great anime coming out this
summer but own maidens in your savage
season is the one show out of all of
them that's been on my mind the most
it's funny cathartic and intriguing in
its storytelling and on top of all that
like on Ohana before it it's one of
those shows that I think is going to
have a powerful positive effect on the
people who watch it if you're not one of
those people I urge you to change that
you can watch Oh maidens in your savage
season right now on high dive where new
episodes are being simulcast every week
and of course you can pick up the first
three volumes to read for yourself on
book Walker that said if you want to
spend a bit more time on YouTube before
you go watch it ya see and I just put
out a review of the audacious seasick
eye light novel JK haru is a sex worker
in another world over on our second
